Devised Theatre: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama        Devised Theatre Practicum:Spoken Word and Hip Hop Theatre  H28.0665 Lecture 4 Credits Instructor(s): Daniel Banks In this course we will explore how to create theatre out of contemporary rhythms, movements, stories, politics and aesthetics. This work will revolve around the central questions: What is Hip Hop Theatre? What is a Hip Hop Theatre production, in terms of style, structure and form? What is Hip Hop Theatre’s relationship to spoken word and poetry? Splitting our time between praxis and "book learning," we will briefly review the history of the spoken word movement, from Beat and Last Poets, to Choreopoems, to slams, and the origins of Hip Hop culture and its commodification by the record industry. We will then examine contemporary groups that use the above aesthetics in their work. Some of these practitioners will come in to do workshops with us in specific skills such as beatboxing and Playback Theatre, lyricism, and storytelling. Participants will also be expected to take a few classes or workshops outside of the NYU context with experts in the field. Students should come with a working knowledge of the history of Hip Hop culture and the major areas of cultural production (MC’ing, B’boying, Tagging, and DJ’ing). A suggested reading list and film/videography will be available for students who need to do summer research to be prepared. All students will be expected to read Hip Hop America by Nelson George, The Hip-Hop Generation by Bakari Kitwana, and The New H.N.I.C. by Todd Boyd by the first day of class (available at NYU Bookstore). At the end of the semester we will do an open presentation of individual and group work.    Enrollment by permission only. Access code required. Please send an email stating your interest, experience, and vision for this developing genre of theatre to daniel.banks@nyu.edu . Curriculum Overview: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Drama Drama News & Events Box Office About The Program How To Apply Faculty Administration Student Center Production Resource Office Production Archive High School Programs Summer in Drama Alumni FAQ  home > Drama        Curriculum Overview  Acting: The acting training is ensemble-based, requiring the student actor to always be exercising their craft in relation to a room of collaborators. The ultimate aim for the Playwrights’ actor, is to emerge after six to eight semesters, skilled at both transforming and collaborating.In the first year, every student takes two acting classes; a basic technique class that draws on a variety of techniques to ground the young actor in the reality of doing and a more physical, character-oriented class that encourages students to explore physical impulse as the generator of character and emotional truth.Second year students collaborate as an ensemble focusing on being alive in the room at all times. As they work with a single text all year students collaborate on telling the story of the play, while learning how to synthesize voice, movement, and alignment into their acting. Having been grounded in emotional truth in first year, by the end of second year students have become increasingly crafty story-tellers.The focus is on style, character, and performance at the Advanced level. Acting classes are all scene-study based, and cover a variety of styles and genres, from classical to contemporary. Students perform in one of a variety of faculty-directed productions, giving them a true company experience and requiring them to put their ever-increasing knowledge into practice. The productions provide students the opportunity of working with professional actors from the faculty and/or graduates of the school. By the end of three years, the Playwrights’ actor is a savvy theater collaborator, capable of working with a variety of genres, styles, and directors. Design: The combination of developing a visual sensibility and vocabulary through reading, research, and hands-on work allows each student to become a thoughtful designer. The pursuits of a designer are rarely solitary; therefore students are paired with one another to act in director-designer collaborations, starting in their first year, in both classwork and directing projects. The curriculum places a strong emphasis on process rather than product. Students are taught the basics of drafting and model making as tools in which to explore their ideas. Students are urged to work in a rough fast style to allow their thought processes to become three-dimensional. Greater challenges met over multiple drafts increase each student’s store of skills and content knowledge, allowing the students to more confidently approach future artistic exploration. All three years of classwork involve classmate feedback, allowing students’ work to thrive through a free flow of observations, risk taking, and critiques. In their fourth year, students work on faculty-led productions to push their work and level of collaboration further. Devised Theater: In the fall semester, Fundamentals of Directing (required for all first year students), is structured to have the students build scene work of their own making in collaborative groups, which introduces them to the basics of devising and collective creation.Creating Original Work I (fall, required for all second year students) offers students the opportunity to build 5-7 minutes of their own performance material. Students are required to work alone, and must perform in the piece. Focus is on development through redrafting, identifying patterns in personal creative process, constructive feedback models, and building muscles for self-assessment. The spring semester students build a 10-minute project. They may work solo again, or with up to 2 collaborators. Both semesters culminate in an open showing for an invited audience. At the advanced level, students spend a semester building fully produced independent projects (ranging from 30 minutes to full-length), which comprise the bulk of their training for the semester. Each student is guided through the semester’s work by both the Program Head and a project mentor. Additional classes within the curriculum offer support skill sets and opportunities to experiment with rehearsal process. Directing: The foundation of the Directing Program at Playwrights Horizons Theater School lies in an approach to directing plays that balances leadership with collaboration. This balance, which is hard for even seasoned professionals to achieve, is a particular challenge to college-age students, whose own identities, social skills, and peer interactions are constantly evolving during their years at NYU. We work to give them concrete directorial tools, first-hand experience (not only in directing but in other areas of theater-making as well), as well as examples and role models among the diverse directing faculty and mentors with whom they come into contact during their time at PHTS. Movement: The Movement Curriculum at PHTS is focused on the student discovering what their own unique, individual body is capable of as an expressive instrument and then expanding and pushing that territory as far as it can go. In the first year, they are immersed in Contact Improvisation and Ensemble-based Composition, learning that their bodies are capable of much more than they ever thought, that their physical being is a vital part of acting, performing, and creating, and that communication can begin with the physical. In the second year, students explore more advanced forms of improvisation, such as Forsythe-based improvisation technologies or explorations with leading contemporary dance practitioner/educators from companies like Susan Marshall. As well, they further their strength, lexibility, and endurance training and enter in the process of learning choreography and repertory forcing them to become fluid, adept, specific, and consistent with their bodies as dancers, actors, and performers. In the advanced training years, a variety of courses are offered to follow the training of the first two years. These include Contemporary Technique (Cunningham, et al), Butoh, Choreography, Physical Theater Methodology, led by a rotating group of leading guest artists. Music Theater: Recognizing current trends in American and International Theater, the New Music Theater Practicum at Playwrights Horizons Theater School offers advanced students the opportunity to fully immerse themselves in the exciting field of Music Theater. Driven by music, and incorporating experimental forms and interdisciplinary combinations, the New Music Theater Practicum demands a rigorous commitment to craft, the flexibility to incorporate the ever-expanding opportunities presented by new media, and the intellectual rigor to participate as a full collaborator in the development of new work. Playwrights’ project-driven methodology offers a fertile landscape for the ambitious Music Theater artist. Emerging and professional lyricists, composers and writers are commissioned to work hand-in-hand with NMTP students in the creation, development and presentation of original new work. From inception-to-performance, course work is designed not only to support the skills necessary for a specific piece, but also to build the discipline and flexibility necessary for long-term success in this exciting, demanding and ever-expanding field. Forging collaborative relationships with their professional peers, NMTP students effectively bridge the gap from student to professional experience. Playwriting: Students are introduced to Playwriting in their Freshman Year with The Living Text which they use to explore their own writing and existing material to gain a closer, more integrated relationship to text as a practical blueprint conveying time, space, character, action, idea, sound, language and spectacle. In second year, students explore these tools more deeply in the writing of 10-minute plays in Fall, and use their writing as the basis for dramatic labs in the Spring in which they can test, explore and deepen their own work. Advanced Playwrights, in their third and fourth years, focus on student-driven projects in a workshop setting: this may be a series of shorter plays, a full length play or a musical piece. The nature of Playwriting Projects may vary depending on the needs of the piece from a staged reading, to workshop productions of more finished work. Voice & Speech: The first year of voice and speech training focuses on developing the expressive range of the human voice and the intricacies of speaking American English. Second year focuses on developing fluid, connected speech in the context of acting classical poetic texts while looking at language skills and phonetic interpretive needs and choices as well as furthering the development of the voice through the introduction of Fitzmaurice Voice-work. Advanced Voice and Speech builds on the core voice and speech skills with a focus on “non-linear” dynamics of creative performance utilizing a combination of holistic and movement approaches to acting. Third year speech emphasizes the advancement of dialect work. In fourth year, the focus shifts almost entirely to the application and coaching of previously developed skills as the student performs in a a full length play, where the teacher takes on the role of vocal coach, facilitating the vision of the play, actors, and director.
